entry.et: Middle English widewe, from Old English wuduwe; akin to Old High German wituwa widow, Latin vidua, Sanskrit vidhavā, Latin -videre to separate

def.dt: :a woman who has lost her husband by death and usually has not remarried
:a woman whose husband leaves her alone frequently or for long periods to engage in a usually specified activity a golf widow
:an extra hand or part of a hand of cards dealt face down and usually placed at the disposal of the highest bidder
:a single usually short last line (as of a paragraph) separated from its related text and appearing at the top of a printed page or column
:to cause to become a widow or widower
:to deprive of something greatly valued or needed

entry.et: from the widow's cruse of oil that miraculously supplies Elijah during a famine (I Kings 17:8–16)

def.dt: :a point formed by the hairline in front
:a railed observation platform atop a usually coastal house
:a venomous New World spider (Latrodectus mactans) the female of which is black with an hourglass-shaped red mark on the underside of the abdomen
:a nightjar (Caprimulgus carolinensis) of the southeastern United States
:a woman who has had an illegitimate child
:a woman whose husband is temporarily away from her
:a woman divorced or separated from her husband

entry.et: The Merry Widow, operetta (1905) by Franz Lehár

def.dt: :a strapless corset or bustier usually having garters attached
